seizure by customs officers under s.203 customs act, 1901 of goods believed to be forfeited

whether decision in connection with the investigation or prosecution of persons for any offences against a law of the commonwealth within sch.2(e)(i) of administrative decisions (judicial review) act or whether a decision that may result in the bringing of proceedings for recovery of penalties within sch.2(f).  customs
whether criminal or civil proceeding  administrative law
decisions to seize goods under customs act
refusal to supply reasons for decisions
whether decisions "in connection with investigation or prosecution of offences"
whether decisions "that may result in proceedings for recovery of penalties".  customs and excise
administrative decisions (judicial review) act 1977 (cth), s 13 , sched 2
customs act 1901 (cth), ss 203 , 234 . held: (1) per curiam

the decisions to seize certain motor vehicles believed to be forfeited goods were not decisions to which sub-pars (e) and (f) of sched 2 of the administrative decisions (judicial review) act 1977 apply.  (2) per pincus j, beaumont j concurring

regarding sub-par (e)(i) of the schedule, in this particular case it could not be said that the decisions bore the necessary degree of connection to any investigation or prosecution under the customs act 1901 . no doubt a prosecution may follow such seizure but it could not be said that the seizure had to do with the process of investigation and/or prosecution. however, it will depend upon the facts of each case.  furthermore, in respect of sub-par (f), for it to be said that the relevant decision "may result in the bringing of proceedings for the recovery of pecuniary penalties", it must appear that the decision to seize may cause the bringing of proceedings. in this case, whilst the decisions to seize may form part of a chain which may lead to the institution of such proceedings, one could not speak of the decisions in themselves as bringing about that consequence.  (3) per pincus j, beaumont j concurring, fox j not deciding
a person who contravenes s 234 of the customs act 1901 is guilty of an infringement of the criminal law rather than merely a breach of the civil law.
